Posts.Title: VISIBLE SIGNS OF LYMPHEDEMA - A PICTORIAL LindaLou53 glennie19

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2009 06:19PM Neece wrote: So sorry to hear you are struggling. the pain can be very bad. I had mastectomy in 2002 and took some time to get over that, but the second one in Aug this year was much harder - all my lymph nodes were taken this time and I think that made the difference. Was OK for the first few days but once I got home the pain really set in. Some of the pain is due to damaged nerves (that burning, prickly 'sunburn' type pain) and there's not a lot (bar meds) you can do about that. Rest assured it does fade eventually - after about a month I could not feel it as much (except when very tired). However the stiffness and tightness you can help by doing the movement exercises you may be shown in hospital - if not go see a physical therapist ASAP to get some appropriate range of movement exercises to do - and try hard to do them several times EVERY day - it is a real chore but it does work. Good luck and be gentle with yourself.  Good luck with your other treatment oo. It is a long hard journey but there is plenty of support (including on this forum. Neece
Posts.Title: Pain-Lymph Node Removal dukesm54 Neece

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2009 08:10AM Neece wrote: hi all, I had mastectomy and lymph node clearance on August 10th and will be starting chemo (TAC for 6 X 3 weekly rounds) on Sept 9th. Great to read such informative posts on the topic. I had previous mastectomy 8 yrs ago with only a few lymph nodes involved and this time the post op stuff has felt much harder to handle - the burning, the electric shocks, the 'iron bra' feel (love that term), and I sitll have one drain in which is taking its time to slow down in output. So have not felt really great since I got home 2 weeks ago, but I have noticed a gradual improvement over the past 48 hours which is encouraging.  Not sure how chemo will affect me so just have a wait and see attitude. I have ordered some beautiful hats and head wraps from an online company (a US one, ironically - I am in Australia!) which has a wonderful range of really lovely and stylish headcovers, much nicer than the ones I could find here, so am all ready for the hair loss saga... at least I think I am, I may not feel quite so ready when it happens! I am lucky to have a fantastic 'solid as a rock' husband and a supportive family and group of friends - not sure how I would survive all this without them. Really value reading others' experiences and tips for coping with chemo, so thanks. Good luck to us all!
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2009 06:24PM Neece wrote: hi Delaine and all the others on this thread, Just thought I'd mention - my dx was lobular invasive cancer also - I didn't realise this was less common? I had 4 tumours of various sizes PLUS LCIS and DcIS behind them all. Had a fairly small breast so couldn't believe there was so much activity going on in there!! I start my chemo (6 cycles of TAC) in 2 days!
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2009 03:31PM Neece wrote: Ice cream, vanilla milkshakes, fried and salty foods (unusual for me), potato, salt salt salt. I expect by the time i get my taste buds back in order the Dr's will say "your cancer is gone but we're sorry to tell you your kidneys are shot!" The thing was I am obsessed by food during chemo and constantly think about what I'd like to eat, yet everything I put in my mouth tastes bad! So disappointing....
Posts.Title: Food Cravings During Chemo weesa Moderators

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2010 11:48PM Neece wrote: I have developed lymphoedema in arm on side from which all lymph nodes were removed. A number of years previously I had 5 nodes removed from other arm and was always extremely careful to avoid using that arm for blood draws, blood pressure etc. However during chemo last year I had to use that arm for everything inlcuding chemo infusions! So far (touch wood) that arm has not developed any signs of swelling. However if I had a choice I would not use either arm. They can do blood pressure measures around calf on leg.I have had one blood draw from foot but found it uncomfortable to say the least - and lots of nurses etc are not experienced or confident doing this. So it leaves me with a bit of a dilemma. I use the less at risk arm when necessary but wish I didn't have to. I certainly don't want lymphoedema in both arms!
Posts.Title: stay away from that arm? imblessed2 lovemyfamilysomuch

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2010 05:30AM Neece wrote: Ladies I am have been reading oyur posts with great interest as I finished chemo in Christmas Eve and now have a very short covering of hair - and debating whether I am brave enough to go 'topless' yet at work. I am in a new job and only started there one month ago so nobody there has yet seen me with my bald / short hair look. I think I will wait a couple more weeks and then go for it.I am getting a bit braver lately, for example going hatless to my swim centre (at least until I put the swim cap on) and also yesterday popped into the pharmacy without my scarf. It does take courage doesn't it? My DH calls it a badge of courage actually and I think he's right! ALso TreadLightly I have the same nail issues as you. Just horrible. I long for the ugly damaged chemo nails to fall right off as they are truly unsightly especially on my right hand for some reason. And on my left arm and hand I have to wear a compression sleeve and glove for lymphedema so I feel a bit self conscious of both hands when I go out.

Posts.Title: A letter to my boob Melinda41 JanetinVirginia

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2011 03:26AM Neece wrote: Hi K-Lo, I agree, telling stories and keeping the person's name and spirit alive in our minds is the best thing to do. Zahra was a very special person, a woman from Iraq who fled the regime there and walked across the mountains in the night, in the middle of winter, with her husband and three small children. She refused to leave her baby behind despite the urgings of some who feared his cries would lead to their discovery by Saddam's thugs. They were eventually granted refugee status and came to live in Australia. How lucky were we? She was a brave, generous, funny and enormous hearted person. For a few years she ran a cafe in my local shopping area (that is how I came to know her) and despite not having much herself she constantly gave meals to the homeless in the area.When people asked her why she gave so much away she would answer: 'If I dont feed him/ her, who will?' A huge heart in a tiny woman. Her battle with breast cancer was awful but she faced it with such bravery. She was the bravest woman I know.  We held a celebration of her life in the local school hall several days after her funeral. About 400 or so people crammed into the hall: so many people knew and loved this woman. She united a community in life and after her death. Neece

Posts.Title: How do you remove adhesive residue from the skin? MaryNY toto2

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2009 11:27PM Neece wrote: I too have  AWs that comes and goes in sevreity since my mx and axillary clearance in early August. My PT has recommended lymphatic massage, as well as direct massage on axillary area, and regular stretching of arm and shoulder, all of which I am doing. She has also fitted me for a compression sleeve but this was to assist with some arm / hand swelling, to reduce risk of full blown lymphodema, rather than to help the AWS. Just in the last two weeks Ii have found two small lumps in my underarm area and of course had some anxiety given my bc diagnosis. Had them ultrasounded today and it seems they are more likely to be lymph fluid blockages rahter than anything too sinister - but goodness me the merry go round spins doesn't it? Anyway good luck wtih your AWS symptoms and I hope it eases up for you soon. For me the tretching and massage seem to be most effective, though I notice it gets tighter when I am tired or have used my arm a lot.
